social_posts.post_text:
This shoot in Amsterdam back in March was such a dreamy day full of lovely people.

In addition to the new Kodak Gold 200 in 120 (see my previous posts), I shot a bunch of other films across a handful of cameras (all listed below), and — as often happens — the scans have sat unshared for most of the year.

There are *so many* great frames from that day, it's tough to choose a few to share in this format. I could probably close my eyes and pick randomly, and it would be a gorgeous selection.

Which is your favorite camera / film from this list?

Thanks to @carmencitafilmlab for the excellent scans, @studio13amsterdam for the lovely space, @annadave for assisting, and @wesley for inviting me along to play for the day in the first place.

Cameras:
- Pentax 67
- Mamiya 645 Pro

Film:
- Kodak Gold 200 (Expired 2001)
- Kodak Portra 400VC (Expired)
- Fujifilm Pro 160C (Expired)
- CineStill XX

#film #filmisnotdead #filmsnotdead #believeinfilm #ishootfilm #filmphotography #kodak #fujifilm #kodakgold200 #fujifilmpro126c #cinestillxx #pentax67 #mamiya645pro @kodakprofessional @kodakprofessional_europe @fujifilm_profilm @cinestillfilm @seriesphotosapp

I've been teaching for as long as I can remember. Whether music, design, or photography, there's something special about translating my experiences into concrete information so others can learn and improve.

@kriskulakova and I first talked about teaching workshops together in 2019, while we were planning a series of photography tours in remote locations. March 2020 put those on hold, but that year made us revisit our ideas for workshops and training, and the state of the world encouraged us to go virtual.

This year started with our first virtual workshop, the result of many hours of discussions, months of planning, researching, and curating material, and two careers worth of experience — packaged up into 4 weekly, live virtual sessions with a small cohort of photographers.

For 2023, we've expanded the workshop to cover all career paths — full-time, freelance, or anywhere in between — and all creative disciplines. We'll cover the entire business side of creative work, from pricing your work to identifying and finding the right clients, honing your portfolio/reel/CV, navigating the worlds of commercial and fine art, and so much more.

###

Regardless of what or who I'm teaching, I want to share advice and knowledge I wish I had when I was starting out. This is why this workshop exists.

We run this workshop once a year — a way to set intentions and focus for the year ahead.

There are only 3 spots left in the workshop, so don’t wait. Book your seat now (link below or via my profile) — we can't wait to get to know you.

kristinakulakova.com/workshops

#workshop #careergoals #creativecareer #virtual #learning #careerdevelopment @viewsonic @colorpro @seriesphotosapp

Last February, Kristina and I were walking through Vienna, looking ahead to what we were each hoping to accomplish in 2022. It was a cold, crisp day, and the wind was whipping through the narrow streets of the city, but we were both filled with excitement and energy from the amazing first few sessions of our virtual workshop.

As we walked along Schleifmühlgasse, Kristina told me about her dream of exhibiting her fine art photography. She had just returned from a few months in Brazil and was diving headfirst into a new fine art and commercial photography career, at the same time as we were running our first workshop. I said I could picture her work in one of the galleries along that street within a year, and we talked about what that might look like, and what steps would be required to make it happen.

Less than six months later, Kristina opened her first solo exhibition, "Dancing Around Suffering", in a gallery on that same street. It was a huge success, introducing her art to collectors and curators from across Vienna and beyond, and it set the stage for a second exhibition a few months later. Seeing her success felt like a reward for our efforts at the start of the year, and I was happy I got to visit Vienna again to see the exhibition in person.

Our workshop focuses on building confidence, setting goals, and taking action, and we live what we teach.

It's amazing what can happen when we focus on our energy, process, and intentions.

We start this year's workshop next Tuesday, January 10th — start 2023 by investing in yourself, and let us help you find your focus. Link in the usual places (bio, Story Highlights, and Stories).

Many thanks to our partners @viewsonic.uk @colorpro for their continued support of education and creativity (1 attendee will win a ColoPro VP2776 27” color-managed display at the end of the workshop!)

#viewsonic #colorpro #workshop #career

Kristina and Dan chat about theircareers and answer questions abouttheir latest workshop: Moving Your Creative Career Forward

Limited spaces remaining, details via the link on my profile.

J’aime (@jaimespezzano) on the Cliffs of Moher, 2019

Dreaming in black and white

Pinching myself that this is now out in the world — @leicauk asked me to share a little about the role my Leica M6 has played in my photography and travels, as part of the continuing story around the launch of the *new* M6 🔴🎞

It's an honour to be a small part of the Leica legacy. My grandfather had a Leica IIIa (from 1936, which I now have), and the M3 played a big role in my discovery of the joy of photography (and film) at a time when most of the world had given up on analogue.

Thank you, Leica, for continuing to support the resurgence of film <3

Many thanks to the lovely team who helped make this video happen:

Director: Louis Bryant / @lb_ouis
Editor: Nielsan Bohl / @_nlsn_
Music: Dale Curtis / @dalecrtis
Super8: Dan Rubin / @danrubin
Additional footage: Sarah Barlow / @livingatno.56

#leica #leicam6 #film #filmisnotdead #filmsnotdead #believeinfilm #filmphotography #analoguephotography #analogphotography #kodak #ilford #cinestill #super8

Leica M6 appreciation post ❤️🔴

The response to my video for Leica has been wonderful — it’s great to see my story resonate with so many of you. I’ll continue sharing more images, old and new, starting with these pairings used in the video (I’ll add credits for each film used in a comment below).

Thanks to @ashleybaxter for the photo of me in the last frame 🔥🙏🏼

@leicauk #leicam6

It was amazing to be back in Wetzlar last October for the launch of the new M6 — seen here next to my original M6 (that’s an @acratech Leica M tripod plate on the bottom of mine, if you’re curious), while on a photowalk around Wetzlar.

Here are more images from my recent video with Leica — I’ll add credits for each film used in a comment below.

Thank you all for the incredible response to the video — if you haven’t seen it yet, check it out on my Reels or over on @leicauk’s YouTube channel 🔴

#leicam6

The way we work has changed dramatically in the last 3 years. More people are working from home than ever, starting freelance careers, and even becoming digital nomads and living on the road. We’ve all had to adapt to changing circumstances pretty quickly.

I’ve always had a flexible schedule when it comes to work, being an entrepreneur since my teens, and yet my work life has still changed a lot recently. As a photographer, I see these challenges as an opportunity to document what this changing world looks like up close.

That’s why I’m thrilled to announce the launch of @fiverr’s “Work Life Photographer of the Year” competition, designed to capture the changing face of work. Together, we’re challenging the photography community to capture the beauty and diversity of modern work life, and I’m honored to be a member of the judging panel alongside two incredible photographers.

The grand prize includes $5k in cash, $5k in vouchers for camera equipment, a 1-on-1 portfolio session with me, $1.5k in credit to stay at any @selina location worldwide, and more, plus smaller prizes for the other winners. You’ll find the competition brief and details on the six categories you can enter by tapping the link in my bio.

So, read the brief, find your subject matter, and submit your best work life photos before the competition closes. Let’s capture the beauty of our changing lives together! #CapturedOnFiverr

Thanks for all your amazing entries to @fiverr's Work Life Photographer-of-the-Year competition! It was wonderful to see your creativity and I'm excited to present the winners.

My thoughts on the top 3:

1st Place: "WAHM (Work At Home Mom)" by @camlyncreates (Category: Working From Home)
Every detail of this image feels intentional, making a strong composition even better the more look at it. "Perfectly-imperfect" right down to the look of perceived-discontent on the baby's face. The reality of modern work-at-home, and a scene mothers have lived through long before the pandemic.

2nd Place: "Work Life Balanced" by @fluffmedia_ (Category: Work As A Still Life)
A classic studio still-life, this is a tongue-in-cheek interpretation of the competition theme and category, well-executed. Representing the epitome of the balancing act we are all faced with — work, family, school, and more — this is striking in its playfulness, bold colors, and almost-contradictory cleanliness.

3rd Place: "Education for Light" by @ziaulhuque65 (Category: Working From Anywhere)
Education is one of the most important forms of work — for many teachers, taking the classroom outside is a requirement, rather than a choice, and this quiet image captures a wonderful moment of learning in an impromptu location.

Honorable mentions: 

Working From Anywhere: Mads St Clair, @mads_ocean, Title: Working Underwater

Working From Home: Maria Asselin-Roy, @mariaasselinroy, Title: Quarantine

Working from the Office: Reinold Aryee, @Reinolda, Title: Coordinating Office Days

Working With Technology: Vincent Fanghella, @vincefango, Title: Give Me a Loud Cue

Work As A Still Life: Alison Grasso, @alisongrasso, Title: Where You’re Not

Taking a Break: Stephanie Zapolska, @stephaniezapolska, Title: Taking a Break

###

Thanks to Fiverr for inviting me to be on the jury. It was an honor to review your amazing submissions.

If you need of a photographer or any other creative services, visit the link in my bio to see everything Fiverr has to offer.

Thank you for pouring so much creativity into your photos and for taking part in the public voting. I'm excited to see what you make next!

#CapturedOnFiverr

April 12, 2023 — a supercell thunderstorm "parked" over my hometown, Fort Lauderdale, dropping a third of the city's average annual rainfall in just a few hours.

My mum's house — my childhood home — was flooded that night, and mum had to be rescued by a family friend as the flood waters made it impossible for my brother to reach her (she's fine, thankfully).

The water inside the house was above her ankles; outside it was up to her knees.

I was on my way to visit friends in northern Scotland when I found out the next day. The news was devastating, unimaginable; almost laughable in its absurdity: Mum realised there was something wrong when she noticed a pair of flip-flops floating by her recliner.

None of us could comprehend what had happened, or what it would mean to recover and rebuild. Nearly five months on, I still can't quite believe it.

I spent the next few days making arrangements to get from Scotland to Miami in the shortest time possible. Workshops and other plans were cancelled or postponed, and I did my best to help brainstorm recovery and storage options from afar.

For the next three months, while living with my brother's family (7 of us in all), Mum, my brother, and I worked in Mum's house every day in respirator masks, slowly sorting and sifting through 50 years worth of family history with archaeological precision, transferring what we could save into plastic bins, drying photos, furniture, books, clothing, and more outside (between rainstorms), documenting anything that was damaged, crying over some discoveries, laughing over others.

Cutting and removing the saturated carpet so the terrazzo below could dry, finding far too many photos and negatives damaged beyond repair, and slowly digging through my dad's belongings 7 years after his death. Figuring out what wood was damaged and would need replacing, and determining how to flood-proof the house against future "freak" storms.

This became our daily routine in Florida's searing summer heat, with the air conditioning turned off to prevent circulating mold spores.

(Continued in the comments…)

Last month I took a trip down to the Isle of Wight for the annual Cowes Week Regatta — a mostly-sunny day bouncing around the Solent on a rib, chasing the racing boats, and enjoying food, drinks, and good company thanks to the good folks at @mountgayrum (see my stories for some highlights ✨⛵️)

I photographed the regatta last year creating a selection of images for the Mount Gay team to use to promote this year's event — it was a special one for me as Mount Gay was dad's favourite rum, and my parents met thanks to a shared love of sailing.

Mount Gay has a long history with racing on the water, and their iconic red caps quickly became prized possessions — I even found one gentleman sporting a vintage 2007 cap from Antigua Sailing Week 🔥

There's a lot to share so expect a few more carousels' worth of film this week 🎞️

Big thanks to Farah (@ldnfashiongeek), Jack (@jackcognac), and the entire @mountgayrum team for having me!

Scans by the lovely @kirkleesphotographic <3

#CowesWeek #CowesWeek2023 #CowesWeek23 #MoreThanARum #MountGay #BarbadosRum #film #filmisnotdead #believeinfilm #filmphotography #ecn2 #pentax67 #kodak #gold200 #portra800 #kodak250d

T A N Z A N I A

Join me in February 2024 for an amazing, once in a lifetime 12-day experience in Tanzania 🔥

In this quick LIVE chat with the founder of @theimageofafrica, Antonina, we talk about a few of the stops on this incredible itinerary.

We'll host more live chats in the coming weeks to dive into more detail — only 8 spaces are available so start checking your calendar now.

Full details are on The Image of Africa's website (link in my bio). Hope you can join me!

Thanks for watching this morning's live chat with Antonina, founder of @theimageofafrica, about my upcoming 12-day tour of Northern Tanzania — February 23–March 5.

We discuss some of the details around the price of this all-inclusive trip, including the importance of paying proper wages to our guides, giving back to the small towns and villages we'll visit along the way, the private camps that will be set up for us in more remote locations, national park fees, transportation, and more.

We will also sponsor a local Tanzanian photographer to join our group, and we talk about my extended stay in the country to offer my educational and photographic services free of charge for various organisations.

Let us know your questions in the comments or via DM — looking forward to meeting some of you in Tanzania next year!

TANZANIA TOUR 2024

Antonia (founder of @theimageofafrica) and I discuss the food we’ll be experiencing during our February–March 12-day tour of this amazing East African country.

Send us your questions about the itinerary, travel, food, accommodation, or anything else via DM or email, or here in the comments.

Full tour details are on The Image of Africa’s website (find the link on my profile).

#tanzania #photography #tour #africa #experience

While curating for the previous post, I realized I’d not shared any of my XPan panoramas from last year’s Cowes Week Regatta — this was the first time I’d shot ECN-2 film (250D) on a commission, and I even tested a few rolls of 120 — see the first carousel frame a few posts back on the feed for an example of 6×7 cine film ✨

As a member of the 2023 @iphotoawards jury, one of the lead partners of this year’s awards, @oneplus, asked me to share my top-5 tips and tricks for capturing better smartphone photos.

I’ll be sharing them over the next few days, starting with this classic tip on locking focus & exposure to get more control.

What sort of images will this help you improve? Let me know in the comments 🙏🏼 #open

Credits:

DP: @steveribeirodop
Production: @inkfieldmedia

Next up in my short series of smartphone photography tips & tricks is one I find often helps beginners and experienced photographers: the relationship between Contrast and Saturation.

Thanks to 2023 @iphotoawards partner, @oneplus, for asking me to share some of my top tips here. Teams who support education and the arts are the best — looking forward to a lot more teaching in 2024 ❤️ #open

Credits:
DP: @steveribeirodop
Production: @inkfieldmedia

This next smartphone photography tip is all about positioning your subject when using Portrait Mode — ensuring there is ample distance between your subject and the background helps your device determine what is in focus and what should be blurred, giving you more control over the result (and more flexibility when editing).

This Reel is part of my educational series with 2023 @iphotoawards partner, @oneplus — let me know what you’d like to learn in 2024! ❤️ #open

Credits:
DP: @steveribeirodop
Production: @inkfieldmedia
Model: @elly.searle

White Balance (sometimes called “Color” or “Temperature” depending on your software) is a key tool when editing any image, regardless of the lighting conditions. As smart as our devices are, it’s possible for a photo to need correction if it looks different than what our eyes see — or you may want your subject to be warmer or cooler for effect. Either way, White Balance is important to understand and use.

This is the 4th tip (of 5) in my short series with 2023 @iphotoawards partner, @oneplus. Leave a comment and let me know what sort of images you’ll be capturing or editing using these tips, smartphone or otherwise! ❤️ #open

Credits:
DP: @steveribeirodop
Production: @inkfieldmedia

This last tip in the current smartphone photography series seems obvious once you know it: When using devices with multiple lenses, use the exact focal length (or multiplier, e.g. 2×, 3×, etc.) to Zoom with the highest quality.

Newer devices will of course give you amazing images throughout their zoom range, but just as in the days of single-lens smartphones, cropping an image slightly will provide better quality than zooming the same amount.

Thanks again to 2023 @iphotoawards partner, @oneplus, for supporting this short series of educational Reels. More tips and tricks coming your way in 2024! ❤️ #open

Credits:
DP: @steveribeirodop
Production: @inkfieldmedia

Hasselblad family portrait ✨

Had a great time putting together the recent mini-series of smartphone photography tips with the help of @steveribeirodop ✨

Thanks to @oneplus for supporting the series (and for sponsoring the @iphotoawards) and giving me a chance to try out the OnePlus Open during production — it’s the first folding device I’ve really enjoyed using, and it has a great camera (thanks in part to @hasselblad).

I’ve put all 5 tips in this carousel so they’re all in one place (each has its own Reel, too), along with an example image from each video (each shot on the Open, presented without any edits). Tell your friends and share your favorite tip(s) on your Stories and elsewhere.

More Reels and other motion projects coming in 2024 📽️ Let me know what you’d like to see next 🙏🏼#hasselblad #xpan #500cm

Heading back to Vienna next week — one of my favorite cities — to run another mini-workshop and photowalk with my buddy Jahan (@doyoudevelop) and the good folks at @leica_akademie_austria & @leica_camera_austria. Link in my bio + Stories, et al.

This time we’re digging into high-speed B&W film (3200ISO, pushing film, and the like), so I thought I’d share some images I’ve been sitting on for a while.

In February 2020, I was in Vienna for a few weeks and brought along a camera I’d had in my collection for years but never used: a Kodak Retina 1a from 1953.

I slowly captured a single roll of HP5+ while wandering Vienna’s streets, zone focusing at f11–16, pushing the roll 1-stop (effectively turning 400ISO film into 800ISO) to keep the shutter speeds higher at those smaller apertures.

I’ll share some more from this roll in a few days — it’ll be nice to revisit Vienna on high-speed B&W film nearly 4 years on 🎞️

Developed and scanned by @kirkleesphotographic 🙏🏼

🔍 leica vienna kodak retina ilford blackandwhite film analog photography

More views from Vienna, this time from October 2023 on the new Phoenix color film.

The last few years have been (mostly) good for analog photography: the new Leica M6, increased use of ECN-2 film stocks and processing, news of a new line of Pentax film cameras — while we’re also facing rising film prices and ongoing economic issues elsewhere, I’ll take positive news when it comes.

When Phoenix was released, there was a certain amount of negativity about who was sent sample rolls as the launch coverage and reviews rolled out. The common complaint was that it was only sent to “influencers” — not a term I love, though people with influence have always been a good strategy for getting the word out.

The implication was that if Phoenix had been sent to “real” photographers for testing, the images would have been better, or the reviews wouldn’t have been as favorable, etc. — and that the generally-positive public feedback on the new film was only due to said influencers not wanting to get on Harman’s bad side.

This sort of commentary smells like jealousy, and I get it — there are a LOT of amazing photographers out there who haven’t been blessed by social media’s algorithmic deities, and it can be frustrating to see opportunities being handed to other people when you feel you could do better. However, indignance doesn’t do anyone any favors.

It’s also easy to be jaded, and say companies like @harmanphoto are making a money-grab by selling a limited edition product — though I’d wager most of the folks who made that argument happily took advantage of Black Friday deals.

Harman launched a new, niche product, and you can’t do that without promotion — if you can get the bulk of your press by sending people free product, more power to you.

So, let people be excited about new film! The world has enough darkness right now — choose to shine a light where you can.

(Continued in comments)

More frames of HP5+ @ 800ISO (pushed 1-stop) ahead of this week’s mini-workshop and photowalk with @doyoudevelop, @leica_akademie_austria, @leica_store_vienna, and @leica_camera_classic 🎞️

Whenever I’m about to head back to Vienna, I get a happy pang similar to homesickness (appropriately, there is a word in German for exactly this: “fernweh”); a place I was planning to call home before the pandemic (and Brexit) interrupted, I’m still aiming to make it at least a part-time home one day.

Looking back on these images from February 2020 feels a bit dreamlike — news outlets were buzzing about COVID-19 during my visit. I remember being surprised that there were no border restrictions upon my return to London, as the first confirmed cases in Austria had been discovered the day of my flight.

That trip was full of promise and excitement for things to come: a full Spring & Summer of travel, workshops, documentary filmmaking, and commissions; a few months in Fall set aside for apartment-hunting in Vienna; years of planning, preparing, and patience all coming to fruition.

Though the last 4 years haven’t exactly played out how I imagined (ha!), each return to Vienna feels like a mini-reset back to that pre-pandemic energy and momentum.

Hope to see some of you at Wednesday’s mini-workshop and photowalk — link in the usual places ✌🏼

Developed and scanned by @kirkleesphotographic 🙏🏼
